On 29/11/05, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> On 11/28/05, Robert Watkins <yahoo@...> wrote:
> >
> > Another work around is to have another test that verifies the
> > behaviour up to the point where the exception is expected. This
> > wouldn't be expecting the exception, and so would presumably fail if
>
>
> Which, if I'm not mistaken, would require... dependent methods (being able
> to order the tests).

Only if you wanted the failure of the first test to prevent the
execution of the second. Personally, I wouldn't care.

> > I personally don't like expecting exceptions in tests because I wish
> > to verify the state of the exception, but each to their own...
>
> It seems to be more an exception than a rule, but you can always stick to
> the try/catch approach if you really need that.
>
> What "state" do you usually check on your exceptions? Except for the
> message (which is probably not a good idea since you need to plan for
> internationalization), there is not much in that object, unless you make
> heavy use of your own exceptions (not a very common occurrence in my
> experience).

It's a coding idiom: I want to know what caused the exception, so the
state usually is a set of objects that describe that cause.

So, for example: if I'm throwing an IllegalArgumentException, specify
which argument was illegal. If I'm trying to access a database table
that doesn't exist, specify which table. If I'm throwing a
ClassCastException, specify what class I've got and what I'm trying to
cast it to.

From this state, it's possible to create messages as needed. However,
the test that verifies the exception is thrown shouldn't care about
the message - tests on the exception itself can do that part.

Oh, and I make heavy use of my own exceptions. The one "exception" to
this rule I have are RuntimeExceptions - I tend to use those for
"can't happen" situations (and regularly get surprised when they do).
